google.translate: We may be surprised that a rite, supposed to celebrate the unity of the couple, ultimately shows the disparity of the spouses. Why does this rite lead to their competition which determines, certainly in a playful manner, who â€?the man or the woman â€?will be lucky in life? One might have thought that their shared procreative life would give them a similar destiny, especially since it is the first child they have together who will determine their â€œsign of destinyâ€? But this rivalry, staged in the ritual, reminds us that the matrimonial alliance unites strangers, that it is part of a context of confrontation, between the taking group and the giving group, which is expressed in particular in the way in which the bride is taken to her husband, in the form of real or parodic kidnapping, and in the ritual bare-handed fights which pit the young men representing the husband and the bride two by two. This game between the spouses is in fact only the continuity of the process of oppositions which founds the alliance. This preamble is also thought of as the ritual impulse which will augur their â€œsign of destinyâ€? In other words, what sex will the first born be? The fact that theÂ luckÂ is with the husband or with the wife provides an indication of the sex of the first child. If it is the groom, they will have a son, if it is the bride, it will be a daughter. In theory, only the grown-up woman will have the same â€œsign of destinyâ€?as her husband, unless their union remains sterile. Subsequently, if a man has children by contracting one or more marriages, his â€œsignâ€?will not change, as for his other wives, their â€œsignâ€?will not necessarily correspond to that of their husband. Because the propitiatory rite of marriage only takes place once in his life and only with his first wife. This ritual act, designated in masa by the terms gi vuna, literally â€œthrowing into the mouthâ€? irremediably binds the wife to her husband. Indeed, nothing can break this sacred union, not even death. This is why the widower (or widow) is subject to separation rites from the deceased spouse so that the strength of their union does not lead him or her prematurely to the land of the dead. This bond, which is indissoluble, also confers on spouses a duty of mutual understanding and a power of curse which they can use in the event of disagreement. If the husband wishes to take a second wife without the favorable opinion of his "grown-up wife", she will threaten him with sterility or returning empty-handed from fishing or hunting. It shows that the power that spouses have over each other canÂ [Page 83]Â jointly endanger their fertility as well as their ability to catch fish or game. The Masa in fact believe that the power of procreation is part of a unique function which directs not only the fertility of the individual, but also all production activities. Bad luck at fishing and bad harvests are associated with a form of sterility. We will see later how an individual confronted with this series of misfortunes will ask a child to sow in his place, since his own "sign of destiny", his own body, he will also say, is no longer capable of producing . A similar type of staging is also found in the Day wedding rite which we will examine later. It proves that the bride and groom are necessarily thought of as competitors.

culture.name: BagisuÂ
text: If we consider what the corresponding paradigms inherent in Gisu beliefs might be, we would posit those of luck and the destructive power of witchcraft. The first places emphasis onÂ chanceÂ in an essentially amoral world; the second that of bitter and ruthless competition which stops at nothing. And again the two are related, for while one is helpless in the face ofÂ chance, all misfortune is deemed as ultimately coming from the malevolent power of others, including in this case the ancestral ghosts. For the Gisu, therefore, the human world is ultimately turned in upon itself with no escape, unlike the Tallensi where responsibility for failure is projected elsewhere outside the body politic. The Gisu have no external agency on whom to blame misfortune; their enemies areÂ [Page 215]Â other people whose constitution is essentially similar to their own. In this battle, success, both in pursuing one's own goals and warding off the attacks of others, depends solely on one's own strength, power and knowledge.
note: misfortune comes from malevalent other people

text: In the first section of this chapter it was argued that Gisu metaphysical beliefs were in accordance with everyday realities where authority is but poorly recognised. Unlike the Tallensi, Gisu ancestral beliefs provide no resolution to the inherent conflicts in the familial setting, whether one sees these in the universalistic terms proposed by Fortes or as related to specific cultural features such as the Gisu inheritance system. And the hostility which this breeds knows of no natural limits, permeating all social relationship as the rationale for misfortunes is sought predominantly in witchcraft and those punitive powers of the ancestors which are linked to witchcraft. Luck and witchcraft, uncontrollableÂ chanceÂ and the evil in others, equally uncontrollable, form the dominant explanatory schemas. This exposes a tenuous basis to community life and, indeed, social life is a matter of constant wariness as the intentions and dispositions of others are scrutinised for clues as to their feelings. At a very real level, safety, indeed very life itself, depends upon such vigilance.
note: chance being "uncontrolable from the perspective of the focal individual

culture.name: OvamboÂ
text: It is not hard to explain the origin of the majority of omens. Our primitives attribute a relation of cause and effect to aÂ chanceÂ circumstance. An important personage, a clan chief for example, once suffered a disaster or died shortly after a certain sign appeared in the sky or a rare animal crossed the country, and then a causal nexus was established between the one and the other of these events. This foible of letting oneself be guided not by reason but by emotions is not restricted to primitives, however. In societies considered very advanced there are many relics of attitudes that have nothing to do with sound realism which determine decisions.
note: promiscuous causal attribution

culture.name: SanÂ
text: Any want of success in the chase is generally attributed to someÂ chanceÂ incident. For example, a man, who has had bad luck in hunting while his wife had her periods, will not hunt again when she is in that condition nor will she eat any of the â‰ noe-diÂ at such times. The meat of an animal killed by a dog may not be eaten by women or by any men whose wives are menstruating. This prohibition is to prevent bad luck befalling the dog in the pursuit of game. If, however, an animal is killed with bow and arrow after having been brought at bay by a dog, the meat isÂ soxaÂ and women may eat the â‰ noe-di.Â The remains of an animal killed by a lion are notÂ soxaÂ and may be partaken of by all individuals. Care, however, is taken not to offend the lion which likewise observes certain practices after each kill. After having had his fill he buries the sacrum and haunchbones and covers them over with the dung (stomach contents) of the animal. If he should be unsuccessful in hunting his prey he returns to the spot of the last kill, digs up the buried parts and inters them in another place. This he does to restore his luck and if he should find that the bones have been taken away he will follow the person who removed them right into the //gÃ£us.

culture.name: ZuluÂ
text: Zulu find themselves involved in and affected by the realm of the shades on the one hand and that ofÂ abathakathiÂ on the other. While, in the lives of men and women, the shades in many respects are the explanation to sickness, dreams, failures, embarrassments, etc., to mention negative aspects only,Â abathakathiÂ are the answer to all calamities which cannot be traced to the shades. What incidents occur and are not covered by thought-patterns which associate the happening with the shades are, without further questioning, shifted to the activities ofÂ abathakathi.Â Zulu thinking does not recognize a stage in between the two which would be the equivalent to Western concepts ofÂ chance, fortune or luck. In Zulu society these do not exist. â€œThere is always somebody (responsible)â€? as a friend put it.
note: promiscuous causal attribution

text: Zulu thought-patterns do not allow forÂ chance, fortune or fate. â€œThere is always somebody (responsible).â€?Either the responsible person has had illegitimate and immoral anger as the driving motive towards activating evil. Or the anger has been moral and legitimate and hence the happening which, although painful, does not have destruction as its aim. In both cases the ultimate cause of encounters is anger and, if illegitimate, hatred.

Hunting being an occupation where risks are taken andÂ chanceÂ plays a decisive role, companionship taboos loom large. While the hunt is on, the hunter's Wis and Chn do not leave their homestead, lest they take â€˜luckâ€?to another kraal, nor may they strut about in their own kraal. Wis should stay inside the huts dressed up with top-knot and kilt (402). They cannot touch the hunter's belongings, it would scare the game away, and the hunters might lose their way. If the hunter's Wi or Ch steps over any of his weapons, his spear breaks when used. The hunter's family avoid loud laughter, noisiness, quarrels and vulgar or profane language. They should speak softly. Undisciplined conduct spoils the hunter's chances! During the men's absence certain types of work are under interdict: the women must not touch water, they cannot thatch a hut or cut reeds for it. They cannot touch a broom nor sweep huts, lest luck be swept out of them or the buck from the hunting groundsÂ (ukuShanela).Â In short, they behave as if they were in the presence of their HF and they Hl'd him. (402): â€œThere is no avoidance of the names of animals or weapons in the kraal. No meat is cooked during the hunter's absence, except perhaps bones without flesh on them. Some women collect the bones of game killed in previous hunts and cook them while the hunt is onâ€? In these various restraints luck is secured and accidents averted.

Human destiny is not left toÂ chance. Every man has his place in the world and the course of his life is determined by a series of pronouncements byÂ MawuÂ which fix the destiny of his clan, of the head of his family, and finally of the man himself. This may be revealed to him for he has hisÂ kpï»¿â†„li, the material representation of which is a bag containing sand in which has been traced theÂ duÂ whichÂ FaÂ has made clear to him in a special rite. Thus it may be said that there are categories of fate apportioned to men as individuals, and not as members of a social group. Two people who have the same du may be said to be identical. culture.name: HausaÂ
text: In Batagarawa men are never insulated from the consequences of their own incompetence by virtue of their ownership of scarce resources. An incompetent man is bound to fail and to go on failing. A competent man, who has already established himself, and whose family circumstances are favourable, stands a goodÂ chanceÂ of continued success. As we shall see (p. 185) the concept of economic â€˜luckâ€?(Â arzikiÂ ) is a positive one, involving both prosperity and good fortune. Either a man possesses this attribute (beingÂ mai arzikiÂ ), or he does not. It is a personal matter.
note: luck as a personal attribute

text: So much for death as the great leveller. We turn now to the Hausa philosophy ofÂ arzikiÂ (a word with the double sense of prosperity and good fortune), which sees life as a game ofÂ chance, which some men are more likely to win than others - though they, too,Â mayÂ lose. Both Smith and Nicolas have expounded this philosophy most interestingly.

Nicolas (1964, p. 105) sees the gift ofÂ arzikiÂ as the basis of a manâ€™s personality: a man is defined by the power of hisÂ arziki,Â which may be increased or diminished without reason. He may be loaded with the good things of this world, enjoy good health, be the head of a large family and yet if he loses hisÂ arzikiÂ he will be stripped of all he possesses. Anyone who lacksÂ arzikiÂ must abandon all hope of enhancing his economic standing, his prestige, his enjoyment of life. He who is endowed withÂ arzikiÂ must risk everything in the game ofÂ chance.

In 1955 Smith asserted (Â ibid.,Â p. 14) that political power and trade were â€˜the only two avenues toÂ arzikiÂ in Zaria at the presentâ€? As eligibility for political power is greatly limited by birth, â€˜those so unfortunate as to lack this qualification seek fortune through clientage or tradeâ€? He sought to apply the notion of an â€˜appropriate type and degree ofÂ arzikiâ€™Â to each â€˜occupational classâ€?- thisÂ [Page 186]Â being an approach which was dropped in his later analysis (1959) of the Hausa system of social status. Nicolas, also, mainly discussesÂ arzikiÂ in reference to traders, as this enabled him the better to pursue his analogy with games ofÂ chance. But in noting that whole â€˜local communitiesâ€?might be endowed with particularÂ arziki,Â he specifically mentions successful farming as one of their attributes.

culture.name: IgboÂ
text: In most, if not all West African societies, events are rarely attributed to pureÂ chanceÂ but rather are seen as determined, as is the course of one's life, by the actions of spirits, both deities and ancestors, and by one's pre-ordained destiny. The various systems of divination are means by which ignorant humans come into contact with those forces which shape their existence and obtain the necessary techniques or information with which to alter their otherwise inexorable fate.
note: generalize over all west african societies

culture.name: TallensiÂ
text: YinÂ is the shortened form ofÂ NaawunÂ orÂ Naayin,Â the Tale term which can best be translated as Heaven. But whereasÂ NaawunÂ is concerned with all mankind, each person'sÂ YinÂ belongs uniquely to that person. It is the symbol of his individuality, of what makes his life history different in his own eyes from that of every other person. If he falls ill he is enduring something that is the common human lot, and he tries to cope with his illness by the same measures that anybody else would take. But, he asks himself, why should he have fallen ill just at this time and not his brother or somebody else, for instance. When he kills an animal in the hunt, or buys a cow, or marries, or has a child he goes through experiences that every man has, and his social personality takes on attributes that are part of the social personality of every man of about the same stage of social maturity. Yet they are his own private experiences. They form part of the unique continuity of his personal development. None of them was inevitable. They are due to the intervention ofÂ chanceÂ in his life; or, as the Tallensi believe, to the action of the mystical agencies that dictate the course of human life.
note: "chance" as mystical agencies

text: These, very briefly, are the ideas, as nearly as one can translate them into our modes of thought, behind the Tale notion ofÂ Yin.Â It is a mystical notion because their ideas of causality are couched in a ritual idiom and are rooted in ritual beliefs; and it serves several ends. Tallensi do notÂ [Page 228]Â conceive of the inner life of the individual as a distinct phenomenon apart from the external, material, and social facts of his life. But they understand clearly that each person is unique as an individual. The notion ofÂ YinÂ is the means by which they visualize the connexion between the material and social facts of the person's life and his individuality. It enables them, also, to see a tendency and a determinism in the life of the individual by reference to which they make the intervention ofÂ chanceÂ intelligible and emotionally tolerable.
note: promiscuous causal attribution; each individual is unique and

text: But a man's most important Yin is that with which certain of his ancestors are associated. This too may come to him in childhood, though it does so more commonly in early manhood. Usually it manifests itself to him through an accident or aÂ coincidence. Thus a young man falls ill shortly after he has bought a new hoe or killed an animal in the hunt. The diviners then declare that his illness was caused by his Yin; his ancestors so and so, and so and so, are thus revealing themselves as his Yin; the hoe or the animal is their vehicle; they brought illness on him because they demand that he should accept them as his Yin and sacrifice to them. The young man will then build a shrine dedicated to these ancestors placing the skull of the animal or the blade of the hoe on it, and will henceforth sacrifice to them on this shrine. This is his first and most intimately personal shrine, and it plays an enormous part in his life thereafter. As far as his own personal affairs are concerned, it will always be his most important link with his ancestors. It is through his Yin that they exercise the most direct influence upon his life and that he seeks to maintain their goodwill specifically for himself. When he becomes head of his joint family he will entrust most of the children born into the family to his Yin as spirit guardian. Every important step in his social development will be registered in his relations with his Yin; it may be by a special sacrifice, or it may be by a change in the location of the shrine, or the addition of an ancestor to the group of ancestors who have revealed themselves ( naam ) as his Yin. A man's Yin is both the chart of his life and the helm with which he steers his way through life.
note: coincidents as predicting something else (Yin, a type of fortune)

culture.name: TivÂ
text: In the Tiv outlook there was not only the survival of the fittest, but what we should call the element of luck orÂ chance. Some died whilst others survived in health; some met their deaths by accident whilst others went unharmed; some wounds healed rapidly whilst others festered; some men contracted leprosy, blindness or became insane whilst others did not. It is natural to get a scratch or a wound in the course of the daily round or to catch a cold at timesâ€”all people doâ€”but if the wound festered and would not heal, or if the cough did not get better there had to be some sinister interference, something that emanated from an enemy in the midst who desired harm. The fact that in this world of such uncertainties some families increase, are healthy and their crops are good or better than others and that some survive and grow old must be due to some special quality or power that the family possessesÂ [Page 4]Â or has the key to. That such people work hard and intelligently was indeed recognized, but good luck required something more than this for lurking dangers were always present. This something wasÂ tsavÂ that they, through the family elders, possessed.
note: luck as something possessed by the people

text: The Tiv, like many other peoples of West Africa, believe inÂ mammiwatasÂ .Â MammiwatasÂ may be described as the sprites of the modern economy. Like sprites,Â mammiwatasÂ are associated with streams and rivers, and the evening, with prosperity and with a readiness to give beatings. When the Europeans were building Makurdi Bridge, theÂ mammiwatasÂ in the River Benue prevented them from going ahead, until offerings had been made. They are particularly associated with Europeans and Igbos; a Tiv who had travelled, told me that he had been cook to an Igbo who had aÂ mammiwataÂ as concubine, who arrived every evening at seven oâ€™clock. Despite the wealth they are supposed to give,Â mammiwatasÂ are viewed rather unfavourably. It is believed they delight in frightening (e.g., by turning into snakes), or beating, apparently without due cause, their human associates. BothÂ mammiwatasÂ andÂ azÃ´vÂ seem to stand for the ambiguity ofÂ chance, bringing prosperity and danger. But the idea of luck comes out more fully in what Tiv say about theÂ mbaahilivÂ .

Like other West African peoples (cf. Ardener 1972), the Tiv believe inÂ mammiwatas,Â the sprites of the new economy. Like sprites,Â mammiwatasÂ are associated with streams and rivers, with the evening, and the power to give both prosperity and beatings to those associated with them. They are associated with European and Igbo particularly; I have known a Tiv who had been cook to an Igbo. His master, he asserted, had had aÂ mammiwataÂ as concubine, who used to turn up at seven oâ€™clock in the evening. Despite their association with prosperity,Â mammiwatasÂ are viewed rather unfavourably; they are said to turn into snakes to terrify their human contacts, or to administer unjustified beatings to them. Sprites andÂ mammiwatasÂ alike seem to be personifications of the Tiv experience ofÂ chance, bringing danger and prosperity in turns, and associated with marginal places, times and situations, the banks of streams, the evening, the beginning of sowing and hunting, and great financial success, of which few Tiv have had experience as yet.

culture.name: Taiwan HokkienÂ
text: The idea of a bad fate is, of course, an explanation that may be invoked in diseases that prove amenable to medical treatment as well as in those cases where the patient fails to respond to treatment from a series of doctors. However, to say â€œit is fateâ€?and leave it as that is not the proper mode of behavior. One's fate may determine that one falls ill with a particular disease at a particular time, but the individual must still seek a cure, and there is a fairÂ chanceÂ that the cure will work. Who can tell, after all, that this is the time that a person is fated to die? As one villager said:

That no single method is foolproof is not, however, simply a matter of faulty instruments or randomÂ chance. It reflects, I would argue, a cosmos which is moral as well as natural, i.e., a voluntaristic system within which freely willed acts are only limited, not determined, by certain conditions.
note: sometimes divination fails is not due to random chance

text: By the time they reached adolescence, girls in Hai-shan fell into one of two determinant categories. There were those whose parents (or foster parents) had sons and those whose parents were depending on them to continue the line and support the elderly. The former usually made major or minor marriages and led what for the time and place can be considered normal lives. The latter had littleÂ chanceÂ of a normal life. One way or another they had to support their parents and provide children to carry on the rites of ancestor worship. Women in Hai-shan commonly attributed the course of their lives to â€œfate.â€?When one sees how much depended on the composition of their sibling set it is easy to understand their lack of faith in self-determination.

culture.name: KeralaÂ
text: These myths recognise the importance of luck orÂ chanceÂ in making money, express scepticism about the possibilities for significant accumulation through normal employment or business, and throw the morality of great and sudden wealth into doubt (cf. Taussig 1980; Parry & Bloch 1989:10). Professionals are often referred to asÂ minting moneyÂ or having aÂ licenceÂ to print money; high-chargers such as doctors or lawyers may be referred to asÂ cash-pluckers,Â the metaphors expressing the ease and naturalness with which these elite groups, still overwhelmingly excluding Izhavas, appear to procure money, in contrast to most workers, who labour long for lesser rewards.

Poor and newly wealthy alike are closely concerned with the forces hindering or easingÂ progress:Â the former as those whose only hope of escape appears to rely upon aÂ chanceÂ coming along, and the latter as those who through aÂ chanceÂ such as migration or business luck have escaped their former condition and must now avoid â€˜falling backâ€?throughÂ dosam.Â The newly wealthy are generally grateful for success, acknowledge that luck and the gods play a part in it, and fearful lest luck should change or the gods withdraw their help. â€˜People want to get money easily, so they doÂ pujasÂ andÂ nerchasâ€?Â argued Appukuttan, a 70-year-old Communist activist: â€˜the Gulf has exacerbated this tendency. Since Gulf migration there is too much money; people don't know what to do with it. It is frightening to make so much money so quickly, so people give away large amounts asÂ danamÂ to templesâ€?(cf. Parry 1986, 1989). We have already seen that not all who try to improve their fortunes are able to do so, while even those with aÂ chanceÂ do notÂ [Page 169]Â always profit from it. Many, like Satyan, the Gulf-returned Izhava owner of a thriving diesel workshop, reminded us that, â€˜God is greatâ€?and that life's outcomes do not depend totally upon our own efforts.Â â€˜Bhagati nammal, bhagati daivamâ€?Â â€˜half our doing and half God'sâ€? is a common proverb. Another Gulf-returned businessman, running a print workshop, thought that success or failure came 10 percent from our efforts and 90 percent from God. Households whose fortunes improve suddenly, leaving neighbours and other family members behind, live â€?justifiably â€?in fear of envy; increasing disparities in wealth provide obvious motives for resort toÂ mantravadam.

culture.name: Kashmiri
text: The child is not just a part of the collectivity, it is also a unique individual. Each child comes into the world with its own karma. Ironically, according to the Pandits, the parents worry about providing the child adequate food, shelter, clothing, and education. What they fail to realise, an informant said, â€˜is that the child eats and enjoys the fruit of its own karma â€? The Pandits subdivide karma into sanchitakarma, kï»¿rÌ£iyamÅ«na , and pralabdha. Karma accumulated in the earlier births constitutes the sanchitakarma while the thoughts and actions arising during the current birth form the kï»¿rÌ£iyamÄna. Further, the life of every individual follows a particular course which is pralabdha. The direction it takes is not aÂ chanceÂ happening, since the sanchitakarma influences the destiny of each individual. When the individual dies, the kï»¿rÌ£iyamÄna merges with the sanchitakarma. The karmic cycle continues till the individual attains release from the infinite chain of transmigration. Therefore, for the Pandits, the destiny of each child is preordained and unique as its karma can neither be altered or transferred.

culture.name: SantalÂ
text: The same anxiety for the future welfare of the married couple is revealed in processes to guard the luck, and to exclude the evil omens, as by the beneficent and luck-conferring virtues of the mangotwigs in a water-pot. And we must not forget that omen-reading is the first essential of all Santal marriages. In this respect, they go so far as to marry the parties to dogs or trees to do away with the supposed evil effects of their teeth having appeared earlier in the upper gum. Nor must we overlook the fact that the married couple not only belong to each other but to the wider life of the clan and the tribe. This communion of the bride with her husbandâ€™s people is ensured by the girl offering rice-beer and tooth-sticks to the bridegroomâ€™s party. And by ceremonial baths and anointing the body with turmeric paste, the SantalsÂ [Page 220]Â want to purify the couple from the evil effects ofÂ chanceÂ pre-marital sex-connections (a rare phenomenon with educated Santals), thereby neutralising the dangers to the family and the tribe.

culture.name: Central ThaiÂ
text: A primary step in understanding these Buddhist Thai villagers' own definition of fate is thus relating it to their doctrine of karma, to which we shall turn after a preliminary view of their vocabulary of fate. The term they use most frequently for fate isÂ khraw,Â by which they usually refer to some personal calamity, often death: one â€œmeets fateâ€?(phob khraw) or â€œhas fateâ€?(mii khraw) when he loses a friend, money, health, or his life. Only occasionally does khraw refer to a happy fortune or humorously to a minor irritation. At times the term may include some measure ofÂ chanceÂ or luck, but more often it implies a karmic influence.

Villagers also frequently use the termÂ choog,Â when referring to their luck or fortune in a more amoral fashion. But, unlike the urban administrators described by Mosel elsewhere in thisÂ [Page 202]Â issue, the people of Sagatiam define few of their fortunes as neutral or amoral: one's good or bad luck is likely to have something to do with his good or bad karma. Two additional terms for fate which I didÂ notÂ hear villagers use commonly areÂ phonlakamÂ (results or consequences of karma) andÂ chataakamÂ (destiny, fortune, based on karma, and perhaps predicted by divination.) It is my impression that urban people use these two latter terms to emphasize the moral influence of kam in human fate and thus use choog to refer to arbitraryÂ chanceÂ or luck. For rural villagers, however, who make little or no use of the words phonlakam and chataakam, the word choog entails a stronger moral element of karma. So far as I know, villagers in Sagatiam do not use the termÂ phromlikhidÂ which Mosel found common among urban administrators.
note: choog, the term for luck or fortune in a more amoral fashion is rarely used by rural people, and more used by urban administrators

text: One's fate is thus intimately connected with his karma, but mereÂ chanceÂ or luck may also be involved at times. Sitting in the temple one day discussing fate, a hamlet headman repeated a traditional theme familiar to most of his listeners, who nodded vigorously in assent:â€œThe old people used to say that thunder and lightning come from the condition of someone's fate (khraw). Lightning strikes a person when his time has come. It may strike only one person when several are walking together.â€?,unknown"

Fate appears to merge with karma for this man and for other villagers who also use these paired terms cited above. For most villagers, however, although fate and karma are closely related, even overlapping concepts, the over-lap is not complete. Fate still retains a measure of unknown, arbitraryÂ chance.

As an illustration the agricultural pursuits of a famer can be taken. The man who plants a crop and tends his fields has aÂ chanceÂ of reaping a harvest, whilst the man who decides not to plant may run out of food. The methods of dealing with the environment in order to have a goodÂ chanceÂ on obtaining profitable results have been handed down through the generations. Magical manipulations form part of the traditional knowledge, and it is generally accepted in WÃ¡d SÄƒancÃ¢w that these have proven successful in many instances.
note: magical practices are believed to influence farming outputs

text: Just as the development of a foetus shows stages which are reminiscent of the evolution of the species, so the individual in central Thailand develops in his religious outlook from a preoccupation with magical power to a concentration on the long-term effects of merit. A young adult is concerned with improving his chances when competing for a wife, and in his eyes the actions of the monks which generate beneficial power may well help him. To the farmers it is no coincidence that the most crucial period of the agricultural cycle falls at the time when religious activities in the monastery are at their peak. The frequent chanting and meditation sessions in the Lenten season have a good influence on the abundance of the rain and the growth of rice. Similarly, a man believes to stand a betterÂ chanceÂ in winning the lottery immediately after attending a major ceremony in the monastery.

culture.name: IbanÂ
text: In a culture whose practitioners hold that â€œnothing happens byÂ chanceâ€?(Â nadai utai nyadi ngapa'Â ), causal explanations are sought forÂ [Page 411]Â everything. An old man suffers a stroke: assaulted by anÂ antuÂ . A young child contracts gastroenteritis; passed by anÂ antuÂ . A mother has a difficult delivery: the passage has been blocked by anÂ antuÂ or by â€œblack magic,â€?so by sympathetic magic doors, drawers, windows and even the roof if necessary are opened to make a way for the baby's birth.
note: promiscuous causal attribution

culture.name: JavaneseÂ
text: I asked him (a young Masjumi man) aboutÂ takdir.Â He said that in his opinion everyone isÂ takdirÂ exactly the same. God does notÂ takdirÂ some people rich and some poor, but everybody isÂ takdirÂ with an evenÂ chance. Thus those who are poor are poor mainly because they are lazy or stupid or sinful; for example, they gamble. Those who are rich are rich because they work hard and are clever. He said that if, for example, he was well-off, it was not God's Will but a result of his own efforts, and anyone could do the same if only he would try hard enough. He said that it is important, however, to give thanksÂ [Page 152]Â to God for one's good fortune. When I asked him if sickness wasÂ takdir,Â he said that there were two kinds: illnesses due to dirt, malaria, for example, and those which are not and are thus not one's own fault. â€œThe same is true with accidents,â€?he said, unprompted. â€œIf you leave here and walk out in the middle of the street without looking where you are going and you get hit by a truck, that is notÂ takdir,Â it is your own fault. But if the accident was completely beyond your own control, that isÂ takdir.â€?,unknown"

culture.name: KarenÂ
text: A number of tabus are associated with signs of bad luck. Many of these signs are incidental to going on journeys. For example, if one sneezes on rising to start on a journey, or on the way hears the cry of a barking deer, or sees one of these animals or a snake crossing his path, or hears of somebody's death, or sees a civet-cat near his path, he must give up his excursion until another day. Otherwise, he will meet with an accident, fall sick, or experience some misfortune in his family. It was once the custom of those who were setting out on a trading journey to repeat the following words:Â â€œIÂ amÂ goingÂ toâ€”toÂ trade.

culture.name: Southern TorajaÂ
text: A pied buffalo with favourable hair-ridges bestows much luck on its owner. Such luck, however, was never the lot of the common man inÂ puangÂ -regions for long, because in previous times whoever owned aÂ bongaÂ -calf had to cede it to the prince as a token of homage. It remains unknown how this dappled variety originated; the Toraja maintain that cross-breeding to achieve special markings, is not done and that the birth of aÂ bongaÂ is a matter ofÂ chance. One pied buffalo can be valued at 10 to 20 ordinary, solid black buffaloes.

culture.name: GreeksÂ
text: The villagers take it for granted that neither impartiality nor altruism is possible in situations which involve one's own interests. They do not believe that anyone, even one's own brother, can act fairly out of principle. Therefore, they feel, some mechanism is required to enforce equity. The strength of their mistrust of the fairness of others is illustrated by a villager's response to a question as to why the mother was not invited into the deliberations. (Mothers who are still active normally have the respect of their adult sons and participate in other kinds of decisions.) The son explained that it was because she might show favoritism toward one of the sons. This explanation was given in spite of the fact that the lot system effectively makes it impossible for anyone to implement favoritism. It isÂ chanceÂ that makes the decision as to who gets which share and when faced with the operation of uncontrollable forces of the universe, the Greek villagers say, â€œTi na kanume,â€?â€œWhat can we do?â€?From their point of view, adverse decisions left toÂ chanceÂ are easier to bear than decisions made by self-seeking humans. Therefore, in situations over which they could have control, they prefer, if possible, to rearrange the situation into one in whichÂ chance, or fate, if you will, makes the final decision.
note: does "uncontrollable forces of the universe" count as chance?

text: Journalistic writing in Greece reproduces on a grander scale the agonistic conventions of everyday discourse. In ordinary speech, people attribute the failure of others to character flaws. One's own failures, conversely, are the result of bad luck, and it is one's successes that are attributed to character. An important character trait in these rhetorical ploys is that of how hard a person works. To many Greek villagers (see du Boulay 1974:52; Herzfeld 1981:564), the attitude that outsiders would call fatalism is really just indolence. Despite itsÂ [Page 648]Â name, it is thus aÂ characterÂ attribution. The few who say they are resigned to the whims ofÂ chanceÂ are thought to be making excuses for their inaction. The morally good life is above all one of unceasing struggle â€?whether against nature or against other people (Friedl 1962:75) â€?even when the cause seems hopeless

Perhaps this form of scapulomancy should not be called divination at all. It purports to allow the practitioner to â€œreadâ€?the future, but one's first impression is that its predictive role is not taken very seriously. In this respect, it closely resembles Glendiot attitudes toward fate andÂ chance. Glendiots do not tailor their actions to negative assumptions about the future, but use rhetorical devices such as destiny to explain the past. In their social aesthetic,Â chanceÂ is not something to anticipate: to do so would destroy the very spontaneity on which artistic self-presentation rests, and deprive men of the opportunity to â€œsteal one bad hour from Death.â€?In the same way, the reading of theÂ koutalaÂ (â€œshoulder bladeâ€? lit. â€œlarge spoon,â€?a feminized form of the commoner neuterÂ koutali,Â â€œspoon,â€?and hence a grammatically appropriate object of male possession) does not fix future events so that they can be circumvented. On the contrary, it emphasizes the dangers of ever relaxing one's guard:Â [Page 248]Â it provides a performative context in which men explore the deep uncertainties that may one day enable them to show off their true prowess.

Glendiot men often display the same ironical agnosticism with regard to theÂ koutalaÂ that they exhibit toward religious matters generally. â€œSometimes,â€?remarked an elderly former shepherd, â€œit happens [tikheni] to show [i.e., the future].â€?But it is clearly not thought to be infallible, even by those who insist that they believe in its general efficacy. The uncertainty of the prediction reproduces the uncertainty of actual social experience, in which â€œchanceâ€?(tikhi,Â here represented by the cognate verbÂ tikheni) provides both the threat of ruin and the possibility of overcoming it.

culture.name: Imperial RomansÂ
text: and favouring the unworthy. To her is debited all that is spent and credited all that is received, she alone fills both pages in the whole of mortals' account; and we are so much at the mercy ofÂ chanceÂ thatÂ ChanceÂ herself, by whom God is proved uncertain, takes the place of God. Another set of people banishes fortune also, and attributes events to its star and to the laws of birth, holding that for all men that ever are to be God's decree has been enacted once for all, while for the rest of time leisure has been vouchsafed to Him. This belief begins to take root, and the learned and unlearned mob alike go marching on towards it at the double: witness the warnings drawn from lightning, the forecasts made by oracles, the prophecies of augurs, and even inconsiderable triflesâ€”a sneeze, a stumbleâ€”counted as omens. His late Majesty put abroad a story that on the day on which he was almost overthrown by a mutiny in the army he had put his left boot on the wrong foot. This series of instances entangles unforeseeing mortality, so that among these things but one thing is in the least certainâ€”that nothing certain exists, and that nothing is more pitiable, or more presumptuous, than man! inasmuch as with the rest of living creatures their sole anxiety is for the means of life, in which nature's bounty of itself suffices, the one blessing indeed that is actually preferable to every other being the fact that they do not think about glory, money, ambition, and above all death.

culture.name: HaitiansÂ
text: In the Upper Belair market, as in any Haitian market, the notion of â€œchanceâ€?(luck) plays an important role in the selling-buying process. It is believed that selling to or dealing with people of differentÂ chanceÂ on an everyday basis would eventually drive someone's business to bankruptcy. According to Haitian beliefs, one is of â€œchanceÂ fiâ€?(female luck) or â€œchanceÂ gasonâ€?(male luck). However, the sex of a person does not define hisÂ chance. Men can be of â€œchanceÂ fiâ€?as women can be of â€œchanceÂ gason.â€?To be of â€œchanceÂ fi,â€?one needs to have a sister following one's birth. Or, if someone is the last child of a family, he is of â€œchanceÂ fiâ€?if he has more sisters than brothers. If someone is the only child of a family, then his first godchild needs to be a female. If he does not have any godchild before getting married, then his first child needs to be a female. If, even though married, he has no children, then his cattle or domesticÂ [Page 38]Â animals need to give him more females than males. The rules for â€œchanceÂ gasonâ€?work the other way around.

The willingness in the exchange process for the seller to know the buyer'sÂ chanceÂ is important since this may determine whether or not the seller will be lucky or not for the rest of the day. The seller would prefer not to sell to someone who is not of the sameÂ chanceÂ as she, in order not to have bad luck. If she feels obligated toward a client or if she is badly in need of money, she will take some precaution during the transaction. It is always preferred that the first person with whom she is dealing be of the sameÂ chanceÂ as herself. The buyer may not care, but the seller does. In fact, anyone who is in a seller position does care.

When the buyer asks if she can touch and the seller says â€œwhat is yourÂ chance,â€?the procedure to determine each other'sÂ chanceÂ starts. The buyer will reply â€œchanceÂ fiâ€?or â€œchanceÂ gason.â€?If they are of the sameÂ chance, the seller will let the buyer touch. The answer will be â€œyes. Do check out what you needâ€? If they are not of the sameÂ chance, the seller will ask a friend of hers to be the intermediary between her and the buyer. This is easy for the seller since she knows theÂ chanceÂ of the surrounding market women. The role of the intermediary is to hold the item and show it to the buyer without the buyer's being able to touch it. The intermediary protects the seller from bad luck for the rest of the day, and the buyer from buying something which she cannot check out.

The determination of â€œchanceÂ gasonâ€?and â€œchanceÂ fiâ€?is worked out only for the first sale of the day. After this sale, the sellers do not care about theÂ chanceÂ of their clients. Good luck or bad luck from selling first to the right or wrong person is supposed to affect the selling prospect of the entire day. So a female seller with a â€œchanceÂ gasonâ€?is likely to deal with a male buyer of â€œchanceÂ gasonâ€?while she will be reluctant to deal with a female buyer with a â€œchanceÂ fi.â€?,yes"

The sexualization of luck plays not at the level of one's biological sex, but at the level of the supra-sexualization of each individual. Besides one's biological sex, one also has a supra-sex which determines one'sÂ chance. This supra-sex is beyond one's biological sex. In theÂ chanceÂ context, there is harmony among people of the sameÂ chanceÂ and disharmony among people of differentÂ chance.

culture.name: JamaicansÂ
text: A good many incidental sayings relate to the daily life in the household which cannot be directly traced to spiritism. Some of the more interesting of these which Cundall quotes are as follows. Of a broom the saying is, â€œDon't take an old broom from one house to another,â€?and to dismiss an unwelcome visitor, â€œLeave a broom behind the door and sprinkle salt on it.â€?You will â€œlose your friendâ€?if you cut sugar cane while the friend holds one end, or break it across your knee, or if you comb your hair at night. Stepping across dirtyÂ [Page 67]Â water or sewing dirty clothes or finding a louse on your head (if it is generally clean) brings illness. Flinging about a chair while tidying the room or walking on spilled salt brings a quarrel in the family. Wiping away perspiration with your hand will wipe away your luck. Breaking a promise made over running water leads to misfortune. If you mend your clothes upon yourself, â€œpeople will lie about you and trample on you.â€?Peeling an orange byÂ chanceÂ without breaking the skin augurs a new suit of clothes. Sneezing is good luck to a woman if her first-born is of the same sex as the sneezer; bad luck if of the opposite sex. Dreaming of gold means success; of silver, disappointment; to dream of a nestful of eggs means riches; new boots, a â€œnew intendedâ€? fire, â€œconfusion.â€?,yes"

culture.name: ZapotecÂ
text: In this example, metate production becomes a game ofÂ chance. (una rifa). If Luis had chosen not to take aÂ chanceÂ (rifar) on the defectiveÂ trozoÂ his only other alternative would have been to start the production cycle from scratch since no otherÂ trozosÂ were available. By altering his work tactics (i.e., easing up on the force of his cutting strokes and aiming with greater precision) he was able to minimize the risk of fracturing theÂ trozoÂ and, consequently, losing his work. If theÂ trozoÂ had failed to yield a metate (which, as it turned out, was not the case), Luis would have lost only a few hours of productive effort at most. On the other hand, to have begun the production process from scratch would not only have involved a loss of the labor time expended to obtain the defectiveÂ trozoÂ but would have increased the risks separating Luis from his ultimate goal of producing a saleable metate (i.e., each step in the production process has its own set of risks which are not operative in subsequent steps).

culture.name: QuichÃ© MayaÂ
text: The system for divination is complex; and it reveals both cause and prognosis. Divination is used for other problems besides sickness, and a full discussion of the technique must be postponed. The basic principle of divination, is theÂ chanceÂ juxtaposition of occult words and numbers. In these juxtapositions the diviner can read the cause and predict the outcome. But for the true interpretation he must depend on his â€œpresentiments,â€?his intuition, his ability to guess, with the aid of key words what is in the mind and on the conscience of his patient. If the onslaught of the sickness has been sudden, the diviner takes as his starting point the occult name of the day on which the patient fell sick. Or if the sickness has developed gradually he takes as the starting point the name of the day that is sacred to the personality, or, as it is phrased by them, â€œhe asks the question in the name of the personality of the patient.â€?,yes"

If you put on only one sock and leave the other foot bare, you will run the risk of going crazy. If a shoemaker makes a pair of shoes in which both shoes are exactly the same size, his wife will die (H.). You should not tie your shoelaces on the steps of a stairway. If one shoe of a pair happens byÂ chanceÂ to be on top of the other, their owner will make a long voyage. When your shoes happen to be thrown down heel to heel, you will receive money or a gift (H.).
note: if something "by chance" happens, then something else will happen (so it's not really "chance")

text: If some object falls but does not break, it must be picked up and broken by throwing it on the ground, in order to break the evil destiny. If an object breaks spontaneously, this is a good omen for it wards off evil. However, a broken mirror is a sign of misfortune to come, and we have seen that, in particular, if the â€œmirror of happinessâ€?which is given to a married couple on the wedding day breaks, either the bride or the groom will die. Whenever anyone breaks something, all the persons present cry â€œQaza-e bela boudâ€?(â€œthe evilÂ chanceÂ has passed,â€?that is to say that it has struck the broken object). When someone tips over some water without meaning to do so, all the persons present say: â€œab-e rousenai-stâ€?(â€œit is water which clarifies the situationâ€?. To be sure, if anything break on the thirteenth night of the year (sizde be-der; cf. supra, p. 159), this is a sign that someone will get angry. If a die falls out of your hand byÂ chanceÂ while you are playing backgammon, this is a sign that you will lose; the same is true in chess. if the king falls (H.).

culture.name: Mara
text: If a man is very lucky at hunting and manages to shoot many wild animals, he is known as a lasisapa. His good luck is believed to be due to the fact that he is a favourite of the Lasi , 1 1 The Russians and Lapps believe in a spirit like the lasi who rules over all wild animals and on whose good-will depends success in the chase. The Russian name of this spirit is leschiy. Is the similarity between the words leschiy and lasi a mereÂ coincidence, or are the words connected? Vide Frazer, The Golden Bough , Part I, Vol. II, pp. 124, 125.â€”N. E. P. the spirit that looks after wild animals. The Lakhers, however, unlike the Lusheis, perform no sacrifices to the Lasi. 2 2 For the Lushei lashi cf. Shakespear, The Lushei Kuki Clans , p. 68; Parry, Lushai Customs and Ceremonies , p. 14. The lashi among the Aimol and the Vaiphei is a more powerful spirit, and almost the equal of Pathian. Among the Thado the lashi is known as pheizam. Cf. Shakespear, op cit. , pp. 158 and 201.â€”N. E. P. A lasisapa is said to see in his dreams the places where wild animals will be found the next day, and consequently always finds game. It is believed that shortly before a lasisapa dies he sees his own Lasi , generally riding on a huge animal. Vakia, late Chief of Tisi, who is said to have shot more than 700 animals, shortly before his death went out hunting, and came on to an enormous wild boar. He aimed his gun at the boar, but as he did so he saw a boy with long hair sitting on the boar's neck. He therefore laid his gun down, and the boy disappeared; so he again prepared to fire, but as soon as he did so the boy reappeared on the boar's neck. On this Vakia realised that it was his Lasi , and he refrained from firing and went home. He told his friends what had happened, and said that he was sure he would never shoot any more animals and would soon die, which after a short interval he actually did.
note: good luck in hunting indicates the hunter is a favorite of the spirits

culture.name: Siwai
text: CoincidenceÂ may enter into choice of a mate. If a boy and a girl happen to be born in the same neighborhood a few hours or days apart, their parents may be so impressed with the circumstance that they will betroth the two.

culture.name: Tikopia
text: The general rule isÂ coincidenceÂ of house-name and married name; for the exceptions there is usually a specific reason. If two brothers both marry and live in the same house, one of them must obviously bear a distinct name. Again, the name of a man is changed very commonly if, on the death of his father, or other relative, he assumes the headship of a family. He then takes the family name as his own married name and may perhaps not change his residence. Thus, Pa Notoa living in the house of that name assumed the name of Pae Sao and the duties of the elder of the Sao family on the death of his brother some twenty years ago. He still continues to live with his wife and children, however, in Notoa, the original house. On being elected to the chieftainship of a clan the man is always known in familiar terms as Pa Kafika, Pa Tafua, or whatever it may be. Since the buildings bearing these names are now ancestral temples, unoccupied, there is always a lack ofÂ coincidenceÂ in such cases. Another reason for the change of a house-name, as indeed even of a dwelling itself, is the lack of children. A married pair who have produced no offspring after several years' residence in a house will often change their name lest the former one be unlucky and conducive to sterility. Change of name, it is said, often brings good results.
note: coincidences being created to ensure good luck

culture.name: Alutiiq
text: Inherent in the world view of fishermen is the belief that they have a certain amount of control over their own destiny and that fishermen all have a somewhat equalÂ chanceÂ against the sea or nature. Government interference and foreign competition is often blamed for the existing inequalities. The Exxon Valdez oil spill resulted in fishermen experiencing a loss of control over their destiny. In general, the Kodiak communities wanted and fought for more local control over the decisions being made.

culture.name: Innu
text: The conception of change in the universe affecting the welfare of the individual is approachable only through the analysis of native terms for that vague expression â€œluck,â€?which so many of them use without defining. Good luck (in the Lake St. John dialect) is kam(É™)l(É™)nto'h(É™)tâ–? which also means â€œmaking a good huntâ€? while the opposite is kam Î±tcinto'h(É™)tâ–? â€œbad luck or bad huntâ€?( kasË™inu'tcetciË™'m(É™)lo'p(É™)liË™'n, â€œall forms of good fortuneâ€?. The fatalities of life are represented in starvation, freezing, accident, and disease for which the animals, animal overlords, plant spirits, the demons of nature, and monsters are responsible. The individual has only to rely upon their benevolence for his welfare. His own soul is his medium of power in the struggle against their force. The importance of divination in the religion of the region appears chiefly in learning what the future has in store, with littleÂ chance, however, of altering greatly its outcome. If the preceding comments satisfy any of the qualifications of the definition of fatalism, then the Montagnais-Naskapi are pronounced fatalists.

culture.name: Ojibwa
text: Another game of which they are passionately fond, and in which women may occasionally join, is performed in the following manner: A large wooden dish is provided, in which they put a certain number of thin circular bones or pieces of metal about the size of a common button, having one side stained black and the other side of a bright colour; any number of people may play, by sitting in a circular manner around the dish. The game begins by a person taking hold of the dish in a horizontal position and striking it gently on a blanket previously laid on the floor for the purpose, then, by making the bones or pieces of metal bounce into the air, they fall and settle in the dish, and all which fall their black faces uppermost count towards the game. While the holder counts, he may keep possession of the dish, otherwise, he forfeits hisÂ chanceÂ and must give it to the next person; in this manner it goes around the circle. The holder at each stroke he gives must repeat a short unintelligible jargon, by which he thinks to ensure good luck.

The first song of the group has reference to the war charm worn by the warrior, the song being sung shortly before a fight to make the charm more effective. 3 3 Other songs connected with the use of â€œmedicineâ€?are Nos. 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 32, 36, 141, 142, 143. Niski'gwÃ»n said that he sang this song before the battle at Ca'gobÄ›ns' village. The last two words were sung with the repetition of the song, the melody remaining the same. The word â€œballsâ€?was said to refer to the heads of the enemy, which the warrior would cut off and toss about. Reference is made to No. 35, in which war is compared to a game, the bodies of the dead being its score. The charm usually worn by the Chippewa warrior consisted of the skin of a bird, dried and filled with a medicine known only to the wearer, probably an herb or other substance suggested to him in a dream. (See No. 28.) This charm was hung around the neck of the warrior, who believed in its power to protect him. It was said that if, by anyÂ chance, a bullet struck this charm it would kill the man. According to Ma'djigi'jï»¿Çg (see p. 84), who made & duplicate of the old war charm ( pl. 12 ), the bird used in preparing this charm was â€œthe smallest of a kind of bird that flies at evening;â€?it was identified by, Mr. Henry Oldys, of the Biological Survey, as the kingbird, or bee martin ( Tyrannus tyrannus ). The characteristics of this bird may explain its use by Indian warriors in preparing a charm. â€œNothing can be more striking than the intrepidity with which one of these birds will pounce upon and harass birds vastly larger and more powerful than itself. The kingbird is always prompt to perceive the approach of one of these enemies and always rushes out to meet it.â€?1 1 S. F. Raird, T. M. Brower, and R. Ridgway, North American Birds , Boston, 1874, p. 318. It does not fear to attack even hawks, owls, and eagles. The warrior's use of the skin of the weasel, the most ferocious of small animals, as a decoration has been already noted (p. 83).

culture.name: Haida
text: A person who wants to remain respected has to refrain from becoming unlucky and thus poor (7iisanyaa). One does not only become 7iisanyaa because one failed to potlatch (Murdock), but bad luck circumscribes potential sources of harm in the natural world (which is a supernatural one in disguise) which are then transferred into social relationships.Â ChanceÂ can destroy a person's social standing once its manifestations are observed by others. Thus the public is potentially harmful to one's reputation, while it is also vital in validating status. When a person stumbles, trips, or falls and this is witnessed by members of the opposite moiety, he must pay them at a face-saving potlatch (ï»¿Ç¤aan singaada) to restore his standing. If a person capsizes his canoe, he must be rescued by members of the opposite moiety, who, in turn, must be paid for this.Â ChanceÂ events like the above must be wiped out by ï»¿Ç¤aan singaada, which avert charges of bad luck and ridicule. In 1905, Gyaahlans gave a face-saving feast to members of his opposite moiety, the Eagles, after one of his lineage's (Yaaku 7laanas) totem poles had blown down during a winter storm, eliciting jokes by the opposite moiety (Blackman 1977). Seventy-five years later, Sandlenee made payment to members of her moiety, after her husband's tombstone had fallen over, not during a public feast, but in private to relevant individuals.

culture.name: Nuxalk

culture.name: Pomo
text: Likewise, a menstruating woman always gave her husband bad luck in fishing, gambling, and other pursuits where skill orÂ chanceÂ played a part. Furthermore, these effects were not confined to the husband alone. A man, even a bachelor, would not have luck in gambling if any of the women in his house were menstruating, though it appears that otherwise than in gambling a man could not be thus affected by anyone other than his wife.

culture.name: Quinault
text: The Quinault were fond of all manner of games and most of those played by adults involved betting. Although it was recognized that some individuals were â€œluckyâ€?and others clever at cheating, continued success was usually regarded as due to the good fortune of having control of an especially potent gambling spirit. Such a person, it was thought, was certain to win in any game ofÂ chance. Guardian spirits which conferred luck and skill upon their owners were much sought (see p. 150). Athletic contests and games played for amusement were not occasions of much betting. Heavy wagers were not often laid except when the opponents were of different villages or tribes, and this was usually during potlatches.
note: guardian spirits conferring luck and skill

culture.name: Blackfoot
text: This is probably the most interesting of all the plants of religious use. The root, a religious power medicine, was called sau-gas-sim , it was also used medicinally. There are three ways in which Angelica (Fig. 22) was used: for luck in games ofÂ chance, for individual power by ceremonialists and diviners, and for collective power in designated societies. The harvesting of the root was the same in all cases: those responsible for gathering it would first pray; the root was dug while more prayers were sung; and the newly dug roots were tied to a circular piece of rawhide by means of a thong, which was laced through holes along the rim. The roots were kept there until needed.

culture.name: African Americans
text: A large number of the superstitions practiced in the community today seem to be concerned with love, or connected in some way with the relations between men and women. Others have to do with good luck in general, and still others are designed to bring bad luck to an enemy. Many are concerned with physical health. Some individuals who are not really superstitious give a perfunctory observance to certain superstitions, much as a northern white person may knock on wood without really â€œbelievingâ€?in the necessity for the gesture. Others take their superstitions more seriously. Those for whom superstitions have most meaning go for assistance to the voodoo doctors who dispense advice, charms, and spells. The types and varieties of superstitious beliefs may be suggested by a small sampling: Wearing a punctured dime around the ankle will keep trouble away. Stray cats or kittens who wander into a house and stay there bring good luck. Dreams foretell events. If a dream is told before sunrise, it is bound to come true. A woman described a very vivid dream in which her dead father came to take away her mother, who was still alive and apparently well. The next day the mother died. Throwing salt after an enemy brings him had luck. The hair of an enemy can be used to bring him disaster. Usually it is concealed under his doorstep or some place where he will walk over it. An old woman who is a sharecropper believes this so firmly that she never allows anyone to comb her hair or use her comb, and always takes great care to destroy her combings, so as â€œnot to take anyÂ chances.â€?Certain perfumes will â€œholdâ€?a man by magic as well as by allure. A woman can hold a man by putting something in his food. No information could be obtained about what was put in, and this belief appears less widespread than those concerning â€œpoison.â€?â€œPoisonâ€?put into an enemy's food will work him harm. One woman told how her husband died because an enemy put poison in his whisky. Snake poison is among the worst; a sloughed snake skin, dried and made into a powder, is sprinkled into the enemy's food while he is not looking. The powder comes to life in his stomach and gives him fits. The tale is told of one man who had such fits, and finally the snake ran right out of his mouth. The mother of a young boy who had recently died told that for four years he had been subject to fits, during which he would scream, kick, and twist his head â€œalmost clear around.â€?The mother had a â€œfriend,â€?and another woman was jealous of her. The jealous one made some â€œpoisonâ€?to put into her food, but nobody would take it to her, and the woman could not come to the house herself. One day, however, when her rival's little boy was playing near her house, she gave him food containing the poison. Immediately the child began to have fits. His mother took him to doctors, to hospitals, to a voodoo doctor, but nobody could cure him. Finally she carried him to an especially famous voodoo doctor, who gave the boy some medicine, which made the poison come out. It emerged in a terrific bowel movementâ€”a long narrow thing, about five inches in length, which had given him the fits by running around in his stomach. At the same time there came out a lot of little things that looked like maggots. Now the child was cured of fits. But immediately after he grew very sick first with flu and then pneumonia, and soon he died.

culture.name: Italian Americans
text: The West Ender's fatalism in the face of illness is due neither to superstition or helplessness. Indeed, the fabled belief in the evil eye that his parents brought over from Italy no longer exists. Fate is rather a reflection of a determined universe, the sacred portion of which is controlled by God, the secular portion by the powers-that-be of the outside world. It is this belief in fate that allows the West Ender to face illness and even death with resignation when there is littleÂ chanceÂ for recovery, and that softens the blow for his survivors, allowing them to continue to function. It is not an exclusively pessimistic belief, however, for the fatalistic attitude also permits the possibility of recovery, and explicitly recognizes the fact that sick people sometimes do get well without medical care. But although the West Ender is healthier than his parents or his Italian ancestors, physical or emotional breakdowns, serious injuries at work, and early deaths still do happen frequently and suddenly enough to justify the persistence of the traditional fatalism.

culture.name: Puerto Ricans (Mainland)
text: Maria and her family (her husband, brother, one sister, and a brother-in-law) did not select this particular centro. Instead, they were looking for a male medium they had once known in the same neighborhood and arrived at Rosa's apartment door by â€œchance,â€?or what they considered possibly to be â€œdivine guidance.â€?,unknown"

To reach the approved group goals one may seek the help and alliance of God and saints. Prayers and the forecast of the future through dreams or revelations by spirits and ghosts may also assist in bringing desired goals to fruition or in clarifying what is in stock in the struggle that life presents to every man. Among migrants, destiny (the concept of the inevitable) andÂ chanceÂ (the concept of luck or adventure) are seen as playing a part in determining the paths of their lives.

culture.name: Sea Islanders
text: Professional witch doctors and root doctors 48 ply an active trade and are employed in the more extreme cases, but often the people take matters in their own hands and by means of conjure bags and charms seek to alter their own destinies and those of their neighbors. Retribution is brought to bear on an enemy, the favor of a loved one is gained, and luck in business or in games ofÂ chanceÂ is assured by the possession of some sort of luck charm or powder. 8

culture.name: Eastern Apache
text: Most contests ofÂ chanceÂ and skill involve gambling, and it behooves anyone who wagers seriously to have his luck ceremonially safeguarded: There is a ceremony for luck in games and gambling, for luck in the hoop-and-pole game, for foot-racing and other games. When a person has a ceremony for any of these, he is usually a â€œprofessional.â€?He depends on it to win big stakes. Ceremonies like these are among the most secret ones, for a man doesn't want others to know too much about it and spoil his luck. You can get a man to talk about anything but this and witching usually. Ceremonies for luck are mostly in connection with racing, the hoop-and-pole game, stave games, and the moccasin game, for these are the big betting games. Singing or ceremony for luck is not carried on for the ball game or shinny. They aren't betting games but are more for exercise, although, of course, people bet on them too.

Propositions about the nature and structure of the universe are seldom made explicit, even by the most articulate Navahos, but inferences made from regularities in behavior indicate that the Navaho view the universe as an orderly and lawful one in which everything is interrelated. To a degree, the conception is essentially one of a â€œmachineâ€?which runs according to certain rules. 3 3 Although the notion of causality lays heavy emphasis upon the universe as a â€œmachine,â€?Navahos are not thorough-going positivists; i.e., mountains and other natural phenomena have their â€œinner formsâ€?as well as the outer forms which are perceivable by sense data. At the beginning, certain events resulted from the will of the â€œHoly People,â€?but once the â€œmachineâ€?was set in motion, it has run according to the rules which even the divinities must now follow. In this universe, man is not at the capricious will of the gods, but is an integral part of the â€œmachine.â€?If man has the requisite knowledge of the rules, he can influence events in the universe. Our conception of â€œgood luckâ€?is apparently absent. Even in our â€œgames ofÂ chance,â€?which Navahos have learned to play, one operates with knowledge of the ritual which will bring success. 4 4 Kluckhohn, 1949, pp. 361â€?2.

culture.name: Western Apache
text: These charms were not good for gambling or hunting or cropsâ€”just for war. Some men did not like these charms, for if you had one, it took your luck away from hunting and gambling, spoiled yourÂ chancesÂ in these for you, as it sort of held your life over there where war was, and you had already lots of good luck from it for war, so it held luck back from other things. You already had all that was coming to you. But men who like to go to war like to have these.

culture.name: Manus
text: Anxiety in Manus is always very marked. Every man is worried, irritable, apprehensive, restless, counting and recounting his debts. Every man is running an endless race with his own obligations, playing one creditor off against another, apportioning his goods among half a dozen different demands. In this there is always aÂ chanceÂ that he may make a misstep; that he may slight one interest claim in favor of another. And should he do so, he fears that he will suffer supernatural punishment; he does not fear that his neighbor will poison him, sorcerize him, fight him, or take him to court. By attributing to the ghosts an active and rather vindictive solicitude for the moral code and an active partisan interest in their ward households, bad luck is made at once slightly impersonal and yet completely explicable.

culture.name: Orokaiva
text: It is this anomaly that appears to have been coped with by the New Guinea gambling system. The game called laki (lucky) is supposedly a game of pureÂ chanceÂ but ifÂ chanceÂ is with you it shows that a powerful ancestor is supporting you. Your luck at the game shows your spiritual resources just as luck at gardening shows this. It is the people with weaker ancestors who lose. Medicines are also used to improve luck, but they are secondary. Evidence for supranatural intervention is that the results of the game, instead of being random as one would expect from the rules, always favour the same individuals. Whether these individuals play honestly I cannot tell, as the game goes on day and night and only a very weak lantern is used at night, my tilley lamp being considered unsuitable.
note: winning in games as a sign that he is favored (has) strong ancestors

culture.name: Maori
text: In most, if not all cases, the objects at which the simple uruuru whenua ceremony was performed, were viewed as tipua, and such places were treated with respect. As to the origin of a tipua rock or tree, should an important personÂ chanceÂ to die while on a journey, or should bearers of a corpse stop at a place to rest, then any prominent stone, rock or tree at on near such spot might be viewed hence forth as representing the defunct one, and as a tipua. Natives have told me that it absorbed the wairua or soul of the deceased, which endowed the tipua object with mana or force, inherent powers. Travellers would deposit their simple offering at such an object, not only to secure good luck, such as fine weather for their journey, bat also to uphold the mana of the tipua, that is the innate powers of the talismanic object. The offering, and the brief utterance accompanying it, showed that the observers still kept green the memory of their ancestor and still upheld his mana. A stream in which a dead body has been washed has been treated as a tipua, and in this case the offering consisted in some cases of a stone cast into it. Should any witless person pollute a tipua object by taking near it any cooked article of food, it was believed that the powers of the wairua vivifying the tipua would destroy such person. Natives tell us that, occasionally, when a seer was a member of a party travelling across unknown lands, he would be able to detect any tipua object passed on the way because his spiritual vision enabled him to see the wairua that animated the object. Here it would appear that the wairua or spirit was not enshrined in the object but hovering about it. Branchlets or leaves of the kawakawa and karamu (Piper excelsum and Coprosma sp.) were favoured offerings to an uruuru whenua, those two trees being much employed in ritual performances.

It is unlucky to dream that you are having your hair cut, and unlucky to kindle a fire on the path, when travelling. If, when sleeping beside another person, that personÂ chancesÂ to nudge you, that act is a bad omen for you, but still you can avert the trouble by pinching the nudger, which seems comforting.

Long years ago an old woman at the village of Uruhau, near Wellington, dreamed that she saw a fire on the ridge known as Te Wharau. This dream was gravely discussed, and was held to be a warning of some danger threatening the hamlet. Two men were despatched to Te Wharau to endeavour to obtain an explanation of the warning, and they encountered on that ridge a party of raiders advancing to attack Uruhau. SuchÂ chanceÂ occurrences as this caused the Maori to place great faith in dreams. The old woman's wairua had, during a jaunt abroad, seen this danger threatening its basis, and had returned to warn that basis. Such is the reasoning of the Maori.
note: misfortune predicted by dream; "chance" misfortunes reinforces the validity of dreams

culture.name: Tongans
text: Since the monarch is not viewed by Tongans generally as a creation ofÂ chanceÂ but rather of God's ordinance, the status of his being must be upheld with proper rituals. Not performing what is considered right can be seen as disrespect to the hierarchy, and disrespect to the hierarchy is seen as breaking an important social tapu which will bring mala to people concerned. To this end, people would go without good food for days and spend much on customary feasts. Those who do so argue that it is much more important for the Tongan people as a whole to feel well socially than physically.

culture.name: Saramaka
text: The distinctive character of Saramaka social life is molded also by another, quite different set of assumptions, involving the place of Man in the Universe. Saramaka cosmology is grounded in the belief that every event has a determinate cause which is, potentially at least, discoverable through divination; the concepts of Fate orÂ ChanceÂ are not germane to Saramaka thought. 7 7 Hurault claims, on the contrary, that in Aluku, hunting mishaps and even death may be attributed toÂ chance. But he arrives at this conclusion by mis-translating ongooku as â€?accident naturel â€?(1961:237). OngÃ³Ã³ku , in Saramaka at least, happens to include the class of events English or French refers to as â€?accident â€?(or Dutch as â€?ongeluk â€?, but means instead â€œespecially evil misfortune,â€?whose very specific causes must be determined and acted on in each case. There is a relentless insistence on determinacy, what might seem almost like an obsession with causality, (a concern which LÃ©vi-Strauss suggests is the defining feature of magical thought in general [1962:18]). Sociologically, the key belief is that Man is the ultimate source of Evil in the world; the cause of all misfortunes are human misdeeds â€?whether ancient offenses, current sacrileges, or current social crimes. And, just as all misfortune stems from human wrongs, every offense will someday bear its bitter fruit. Historicity in Saramaka is very much a two-way street.

The younger KaapÃªltÃ¹k, the research assistant council, and I spent a number of days studying â€œchanceâ€?as a concept. They were familiar with the word for â€œaccidentâ€?in Portuguese ( acidente ), but this term could be applied only to an automobile accident. I tried to apply it to events concurring by accident (chance), but this concept was not acceptable. For these research assistants, everything that occurred had to have an antecedent cause or set of preceding causes, and the cause or causes could not be random placement or timing: elements or events coming together coincidentally. Thus, because of the lack of a key expression in the semantic area for â€œchance,â€?I concluded that there is no such Canela concept, at least not in the Western sense. This observation is supported by the limited degree to whichÂ chanceÂ enters into any of their sports and games [II.F. 3 ], and into their life in general.
